direction.raw_text: A man conducting Beethoven.  Air raid in progress.  Bombs falling nearby.  The orchestra continues to play.  Suddenly the lights go out.  The music stops. INT. BACKSTAGE CORRIDOR, CONCERT HALL - NIGHT A beam from a torch, bouncing, making shadows.  An ATTENDANT, carrying the torch, hurries down the corridor. The air raid continues. He comes to a door, knocks, opens it and looks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sound of heavy footsteps approaching.  The attendant turns his torch to light the way for three men in Nazi uniform, also with attendants and torches, marching down the corridor. The attendant bows deeply as the REICHSMINISTER and his aide go through the door. The other man remains in the corridor on guard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (agitated) Dr. Furtwangler, the Reichsminister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Candles light the room where the conductor shakes hands with the Reichsminister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bomb explodes nearby.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Furtwangler, I want to apologise personally for this power failure. I was so enjoying the performance. In times like these we need spiritual nourishment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I welcome this unexpected opportunity of talking to you. (with great care) When you came on to the platform tonight, I thought you weren't well.  You looked tired, (a warning) Get away from this bombing. Away from the war.  Yes, you look tired... (a crooked smile) Even in this light.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dark.  ON A SCREEN: scenes from Leni Riefenstahl's triumph of the will. Over this:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The film changes with a scratchy music soundtrack - Wagner. SHOTS of high-ranking Nazis in an audience including Josef Goebbels, listening. And they're listening to and watching Wilhelm Furtwangler conducting. At the appropriate moment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Nazis applaud. Goebbels shakes hands with Furtwangler. The film ends. Sitting in the ruined cinema are two men: GENERAL WALLACE, with files on the table, and, beside him, MAJOR STEVE ARNOLD. A PROJECTIONIST is standing in the door of the projection room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace glances at the file.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve wants to rise, but Wallace puts a hand on his shoulder to make him sit again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods to the projectionist, then starts to go, but stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace goes. The projectionist starts the next reel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look at them. Men, women, kids. Boy, did they love him. You see, Steve, Adolf Hitler touched something deep, real deep and savage and barbaric, and it won't just go away overnight. It's got to be rooted out. You know what I think? I think they were all Nazis. And let's face it, their leaders, those bastards now on trial in Nuremberg, couldn't have done it alone. It's these people, they gave all the help that was needed. Willingly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's him.  Furtwangler. Wilhelm Furtwangler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, you never heard of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know who Arturo Toscanini is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's as big as Toscanini, maybe even bigger. In this neck of the woods, he's probably Bob Hope and Betty Grable rolled into one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jeez, and I never heard of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were in insurance before the war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Claims assessor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Conscientious, determined, dogged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amused) They said I was dogged?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, they say here that when you went on a case, you stayed on it. (looks up at Steve.) Now we can't take every Nazi in this country to trial, although I would like to; it's an impossibility. So we're going for the big boys in industry, education, law, culture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like this bandleader.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a smile) Well, he's more than just a bandleader, Steve. He's a great conductor, a gifted artist. But we believe that he sold himself to the devil. Your number one priority from this moment on is to connect him to the Nazi Party. Don't be impressed by him. I want the folks back home to understand why we fought this war. Find Wilhelm Furtwangler guilty. He represents everything that was rotten in Germany.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay put, Steve. There is some other stuff that I'd like for you to see here. Background.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, one thing that may be a problem. Our Occupation Authorities in Wiesbaden have a duty to help these poor unfortunates with their defence. They keep repeating: 'We must be just, we must be seen to be just.' Well, I've only one thing to say to the liberals in Wiesbaden: fuck 'em. (as he goes) You answer to no one but me. Is that understood? (to the projectionist in the door) Show him the film.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir. Roll it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : a Berlin sequence. Bombs falling. Ruins, a city devastated, empty. Flags of the four allied nations. Posters of Truman, Stalin, Churchill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve watches expressionless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: emaciated corpses being bulldozed into mass graves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The moment this appears, Steve rises and goes quickly. ON THE SCREEN: piles of cadavers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That is the hand that dropped the bombs on defenceless Rotterdam, Brussels, Belgrade. That is the hand that destroyed the cities, villages and homes of Russia. That is the hand that held the whip over the Polish, Yugoslav, French and Norwegian slaves. That is the hand that took their food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Next reel, please. ON THE SCREEN: SHOTS of camp survivors. Then SHOTS of
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sanitary conditions were so appalling that heavy equipment had to be brought in to speed the work of cleaning up. This was Bergen Belsen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve having a nightmare, twisting, turning, moaning. He wakes with a cry. He is sweating. He turns on the light, looks at a clock, reaches for a cigarette, lights it. He smokes. He stares at the ceiling. Later: Early morning. Cold. Steve is at the basin in his small room, shaving. A radio on a shelf.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Remember, men, no fraternisation. In a German town, if you bow to a pretty girl or pat a blond child, you bow to all that Hitler stood for. You bow to his reign of blood. You caress the ideology that meant death and destruction. You never know who was a member of the Nazi Party. Don't be fooled. Don't fraternise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve's car swerves round the corner and comes to a halt. A small crowd watch workmen on ladders hammering away at a stone swastika above the portico. American soldiers supervise. Steve gets out of the car, carrying an attache case, and he, too, watches as the stone swastika falls and crashes into pieces on the road. One or two people clap, most just stare. The American soldiers immediately hoist the Stars and Stripes. Steve goes into the building. The sentry salutes. The driver of the car goes to the trunk and takes out a labelled duffel bag, cans of film, a case which holds a 16- mm projector. A small BOY sidles up to him:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Cigarettes, chewing gum?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve and Sergeant Adams ascending a grand, winding but damaged staircase to the rear of a spacious entrance hall. A once impressive building. Signs of bomb damage everywhere. German workmen doing repairs. American military personnel coming and going, saluting Steve, who barely acknowledges them. They reach the landing. Adams opens double doors and they go through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few gilt chairs, a workman trying to repair the stove. Adams opens another door for Steve.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We're gonna have the heating fixed by tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is hanging the standard photograph of President Truman on the wall. She turns to see Steve and Adams and is covered with confusion. She gives Steve a little curtsey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes. Steve scrutinises Emmi. She's embarrassed, keeps her eyes downcast. Steve goes to his desk, opens a file, reads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods, goes on reading.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods, keeps her eyes averted. He smiles sympathetically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He searches his pockets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve starts to unpack his attache case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands Steve a typewritten sheet. He ignores it, finds a list which he hands to her. He waits for her to read, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles. She tries to smile back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fraulein, this is Major Arnold. Sir, this is your secretary, Fraulein Emmi Straube. Her file's on your desk. They sent her over from Admin. I'll leave you to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You live here, in Berlin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You do shorthand and typing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, let's see. How long were you in the camp for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Three months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Says here because of your father. What's that mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father was one of the officers in the plot against Hitler. They arrested the plotters and their families.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your mother, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. She suffered longer. She was in Ravensbruck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And your father was executed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm gonna call you Emmi, you're gonna call me Steve. Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got a list of stuff here I'd like you to get for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you need anything, let me know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There have been messages for you. (She consults the pad.) A Lieutenant David Wills called from the Allied Kommandatura Cultural Affairs office in Wiesbaden. I don't know who he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then there have been three calls from Dr. Furtwangler wanting to know when you wish to see him. I did not speak to him personally...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Think you can get me any of that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleased) Oh yes, Major, I have recordings of all his symphonies. I kept them safe during the bombing. My favourite is the Seventh Symphony.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mine's the Eleventh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled) But... he only wrote nine, Major.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm kidding, Emmi. What about a record player? You have that, too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Ours was damaged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surveys the room) What's in those files?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The names of the members of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra since 1934 together with their questionnaires.  Major, what am I to tell Dr. Furtwangler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You tell him nothing, Emmi. If he calls again, you say you know nothing. We're gonna keep him waiting while I get acquainted with his case and with the witnesses. And, God help me, with Beethoven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Freezing weather. A narrow street, crowded, busy, noisy. Some makeshift stalls set out, trestle tables, open suitcases, people buying and selling every imaginable commodity. Emmi wanders through the crowd, passing a violinist, Helmuth Rode, wrapped up against the cold, playing Handel's Air on a G String, a bowl for money at his feet. A passer-by drops a cigarette butt in it.  Immediately, Rode retrieves the butt. Emmi comes to a stall selling piles of gramophone records. She asks the stallholder a question. He points to another stall across the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve at his desk, paging through files. A knock on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lieutenant DAVID WILLS, aged twenty-four, enters, comes to Steve's desk, stands to attention, salutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David half-smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Breaks off. Nothing from Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens and Emmi enters carrying a record player, sees David and starts to back out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They nod briefly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A flick from Emmi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For Emmi's benefit too. She becomes still, listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David takes a few files, sits and starts to look through them. Steve returns to his files. Emmi, by now, has put on a record and starts to play it: the opening of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony blasts out. The two men look up, startled. Emmi beams:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lieutenant Wills reporting to Major Arnold. Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For Chrissakes I hate that shit, cut it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Steve. What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: David. David Wills. I'm your liaison officer with the Allied Kommandatura Cultural Affairs Committee. Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sounds a lot of run. (studies David.) So they sent the big guns to check up on me. We recruiting children now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles') I guess so, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You call me sir again and I'll make you listen to Beethoven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where you from, David?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: was born here, in Leipzig. I escaped in '36. My parents, they sent me to my uncle in Philadelphia. They were to follow. But they delayed and...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our family name was Weill. But that doesn't sound well in English. My uncle changed it to Wills and...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come in, Emmi, this is your office, too. Emmi, this is Lieutenant David Wills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is here to watch over us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess you admire musicians.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't. This is like a criminal investigation, David. Musicians, morticians, doctors, lawyers, butchers, clerks. They're all the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have a duty, a moral duty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It works!  Hallelujah!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Emmi at the door. Steve at his desk. David present. EMMI Herr Rudolf Werner. WERNER enters, bows to Steve and David. Emmi goes to her desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indicates the upright chair; Werner sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Werner nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long silence; Steve watches him. Werner is made more anxious. At last, in a rush:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Werner swivels round to look at Emmi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brief silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sit down, Werner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to understand why you're here. This is an investigation into Wilhelm Furtwangler, former Prussian Privy Councillor, banned from public life under Control Council Directive No 24 and who's applied to come before the Tribunal of Artists of the Denazification Commission. I'm interested in what he was up to from 1933 to the end of the war, understood?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rudolf Otto Werner. Wind section since 1936. What instrument did you play?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First oboe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have your questionnaire here. It says you were never a member of the Nazi Party.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Absolutely not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I was never a Nazi, I have no interest in politics, I'm a musician -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, hey, slow up, Fraulein Straube has to take down what you say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Straube? Any relation to Colonel Joachim Straube?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a great honour to meet you, Fraulein. Your father was a great patriot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Furtwangler is a great musician. He actively opposed the Nazis and later on he helped many Jews to escape.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then how do you explain him being made a Prussian Privy Councillor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was Hermann Goering. I was told he just made the maestro his Privy Councillor, no questions asked. Although Dr. Furtwangler stood up to him. And to Dr. Goebbels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He also conducted for Hitler, didn't he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, that's true, but he refused to give the Nazi salute. He kept his baton in his right hand. In Hitler's presence. That was a brave act...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brave?  To celebrate Hitler's birthday with some heroic piece by Wagner but without the Nazi salute? Bravo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was Beethoven's Ninth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you really think it was brave? Didn't he bow to him and shake his hand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Another man, SCHLEE, is in the chair. Only Steve and Emmi now. Pale, yellow electric light. Silence. Schlee, too, is very nervous. At last:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve just stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve lights a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schlee tries to find words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve nods, thinks for a moment. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schlee looks at him bewildered.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, no, I give you my word. I was never a member of the Nazi Party. Never. I am in the percussion section. I play the timpani.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway, they would never have allowed it. My brother was married to a Jewess, may she rest in peace. And Goebbels said... (to Emmi) ...please take this down carefully, because it's most important, Fraulein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Straube.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (acting surprised) Straube? Are you by any chance related to Colonel Joachim Straube?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was... he was a great hero.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goebbels, yes, Josef Goebbels said, 'There's not a single filthy Jew left in Germany on whose behalf Dr. Furtwangler has not intervened.' No, no one could have been less of a Nazi than Dr. Furtwangler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But this was the same guy who conducted for Adolf on his birthday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was forced to do that. But he refused to give the Nazi salute in front of Hitler. He kept his baton in his hand, you can't salute with a baton in your hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what about the Nuremberg Rally?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, we...we played on the evening before the Rally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (straight-faced) Oh! The evening before, I see...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Dr. Furtwangler was absolutely clear about this: politics and art must be kept separate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Politics and art must be kept separate. I'll remember that. But let me see if you can help me with something I just don't understand. I'd really like to know why all you guys are so crazy about him. What's his secret?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's hard to explain. I can only tell you from my own experience. Soon after I joined the orchestra, we were rehearsing the Third Symphony of Beethoven, the Eroica. There are several rather difficult passages for the timpani. One particular crescendo. During the break, I asked how he wanted it played. He was studying his score. He didn't look up. He said, 'Just watch me.'  So, of course, I did. I never stopped watching him. The moment came. And suddenly, he turned to me and our eyes were locked. There was something in his look that...  that simply demanded the crescendo. I shall never forget his look. It was a moment of... of magic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever seen Adolf Hitler's eyes when he was making a speech? I've seen 'em on films.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was looking at Furtwangler like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what you mean, Major.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you got to the crescendo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the back, David and Steve. Military driver. The car's making its way along a road that skirts a lake towards a grand mansion from which fly the four Allied flags.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You think a whole orchestra, what, a hundred and forty or so guys, could be orchestrated?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess it's possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, what does the Russki want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Colonel Dymshitz asked specially to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Dim-shits'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A huge, cavernous room, once the ballroom. In the centre, a table with four chairs. To one side, antique furniture, objets d'art, paintings. Four Allied officers are surveying the treasures: COLONEL DYMSHITZ, COLONEL GREEN (American), MAJOR RICHARDS (British) and CAPTAIN VERNAY (French). What they say is barely audible, low mumbles. They're accompanied by aides with clipboards, taking notes. Beyond, and some distance away, a row of gilt chairs for observers where David and Steve take their seats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dymshitz, small, intelligent face, cunning eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Green, correct, formal, precise, immaculate. Richards, bespectacled and nondescript. Vernay, upright, proud.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell are they doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispered) They're trying to sort out some of the works of art the Nazis stole from occupied territories. Who really owns what? That's Colonel Dymshitz, on the far side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: art historian, head of the famous Leningrad Museum of Art. He is an expert on German culture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly raising his voice) Je suis navre, Colonel, cette peinture n'est pas la propriete de I'union sovietique mats bien cette de la France.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's he saying? Henri, what is you saying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's saying that picture is the property of France
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'est un Braque qui avec Picasso etait un des pionniers du cubisme.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in French) I know who Georges Braque is, Captain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost simultaneously) It's a Barque. FRENCH AIDE We can produce the provenance of this Braque, you say provenance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Outside the club room for the participants. Buzz of conversation, clink of glasses, cups. The terrace is deserted. A waiter carries a tray with various refreshments to a quiet corner where Dymshitz, Green, Vernay, his aide LIEUTENANT SIMON, Steve and David sit in comfortable armchairs. The waiter serves them. During this:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve makes a non-committal gesture.
direction.name: direction

location: SALON OFF THE BALLROOM AND TERRACE
result.heading: INT./EXT.

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Major, my name is Dymshitz. I'm glad to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Colonel. Pleasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, Major, tell me, have you questioned Dr. Furtwangler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've had two meetings with him. He's a great musician. Maybe the greatest conductor in the world. His Brahms, Beethoven, Schubert - unequalled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll come straight to point. I've offered him a very attractive position. Conductor of the Staatsoper Unten den Linden. He refused. But I want him. I want him badly. And I want your help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, just a moment, you should have discussed this with me first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm discussing it with you now. Major, I want you to drop your investigation, save everybody time and trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can't drop a case just like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll give you another conductor in exchange or writer, musician, actor what...what do you care?  But I like Furtwangler. He's my favourite conductor. (chuckles.) Mine and Hitler's. He's our favourite conductor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rode is seated, waiting. Nervous, tense. The sound of laughter, David's laughter from the office. It makes him even more uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi and David laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He demonstrates. She laughs again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles just as Steve bursts in. He's in a bright, cheerful, energetic mood. David draws back guiltily. Emmi, embarrassed, hesitates then turns to the typewriter and types furiously. Seeing this, Steve stops, but just for a brief moment. Then, as he goes to his desk:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks from David to Emmi as if trying to work out something.  Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later. Rode in the witness chair. Steve studying the file. David and Emmi ready to take notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He chuckles, looks around for approval. Steve grins encouragingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long silence. RODE I... I know everyone now says they were never Nazis but in my case it is absolutely one hundred per cent true. I am a Catholic, it would have been totally against my conscience. Silence. Steve lights a cigarette; Rode eyes it hungrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve flicks David a glance, waggles his finger like a baton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuckles. David mouths I win to Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve and David exchange a brief look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He crosses himself. Silence. David raises a discreet finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brief silence; a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve nods, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode stands and bows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I clicked my heels, saluted and bowed at the same time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's because you had a proper upbringing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. I was raised very strictly. So don't speak before you are spoken to!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh! And don't wave your hands about!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Respect your elders and your betters!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And no elbows on the table!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eating is eating... and...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And talking is talking! Well, I think we better get on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. So, this is going to be very formal, too, now. Lieutenant David Wills requests die pleasure of die company of Fraulein Emmi Straube at dinner any night she cares.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: David, need to ask you something. You heard this rumour the British found something called the Hinkel Archive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. STEVE So what is it? DAVID The British occupy the building where this guy, Hinkel, ran the Nazi Ministry of Culture and it seems they've... they've discovered his secret archive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, but the British are excited about it, I know that. The rumour is Hinkel kept a file on every artist working in the Third Reich.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jeez. And you think the British'll share it with their Allies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major Richards said he'd call to let us know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's big of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, better question the next witness. I bet you a bottle of French champagne he tells us the baton story inside ten minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a bet. You're the witness, Emmi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Helmuth Alfred Rode. Second violinist since 1935. What's it mean, second violinist?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It means I wasn't good enough to be a first violinist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good, and according to your questionnaire, Helmuth, you never joined the Nazi Party.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me? Never.  Never.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it true you're going to interview Dr. Furtwangler today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll ask the questions, Helmuth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me. Did you know that he refused to give the Nazi salute when Hitler was present in the audience?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The problem was how could he avoid giving the Devil's salute when Satan was actually sitting there. (modestly taps his chest with his thumb.) And, I said, 'Dr. Furtwangler, why not enter with the baton in your right hand? Hitler will be sitting in the front row. If you give the salute with the baton in your right hand it'll look like you're going to poke his eyes out.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was...He was really grateful to me for that. After the concert, I... I stole that baton as a memento of a great act of courage. I still have it. I should have brought it to show you. I hope I'm not going too fast for you, Fraulein?-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Straube.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Straube. Any relation to Colonel Joachim Straube?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (standing) I am deeply honoured to be in your presence, Fraulein Straube. Your father was a true patriot, a man of God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have a question for Helmuth, David?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. What was the orchestra's reaction when they asked you to play for Hitler's birthday?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, we didn't play for his birthday, we played the evening before - it was the 19th of April not the 20th.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know Hans Hinkel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (alarmed) Do I know Hans Hinkel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I asked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do I know Hans Hinkel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You seem to understand the question, now how about answering it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hans Hinkel was in the Ministry of Culture; how could I know such a man?  I
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hear the British have his... his archive, files, records.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know what's in this archive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How could I know what's in the archive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, you can go now, Helmuth. Get out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The final bars of the Fifth Symphony. Snowing. Dim light. There is more furniture now: two chairs, one comfortable, the other upright.  A sitting area by the window with the telephone extension. The 16-mm projector set up in another corner. Steve, at his desk, wrapped up against the cold, going through files, making notes. He stops, seems to listen, then goes to the window, looks out. The music ends. The record hisses. Steve just stares out at the night and the snow. The record continues to hiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tram packed to overflowing. Then, a sudden stir among the passengers as people push through trying to find space. One of them is FURTWANGLER. He's recognised. Whispering. He stares ahead or keeps his eyes downcast. An elderly man tugs at his coat, half-rises, offering his seat. Furtwangler manages a smile and shakes his head. The tram rattles on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler approaches Adams at his desk. He crosses to the stairs. German workmen stop what they are doing to let him pass. One of them bows. On the upper landing, Emmi is making her way to Steve's office. She stops, sees Furtwangler on the stairs and then dashes to Steve's door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Furtwangler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Emmi bursts in on Steve and David. She's overawed:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi glances out again and reluctantly closes the door, Steve sits calmly, relaxed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Major, Major... he's here ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut the door, Emmi. Sit down, Emmi. We're going to keep him waiting, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Emmi, get us some coffee, will you? And, Emmi, don't offer him coffee. Don't even greet him, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler sits, waiting. Emmi, deeply embarrassed, hurries through.. Furtwangler is about to ask her something, but she's gone. He waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve and David preparing papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler waiting. Emmi enters from the landing door carrying a tray and three mugs of coffee. She hurries towards the office door, eyes downcast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi bites her lip and, without looking at him, disappears into the office.  Furtwangler closes his eyes, breathes deeply. He stands, goes to the window, looks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fraulein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long am I to be kept waiting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Silence. Steve studying his notes. David watching him. Emmi staring forlornly into space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi rises, opens the door, nods, turns back to Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler enters. As he passes her, Emmi gives him a small curtsey. David nods. Steve doesn't look up. Furtwangler waits a moment, glances round, sees the more comfortable chair and sits in it. Steve looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler stands. Steve points to the other chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A very long silence. When the silence is unbearable Steve speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David puts up a hand. Steve nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve looks expectant but Furtwangler remains silent. Steve nods to Emmi, who gets the water.  Furtwangler drinks. Steve waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Steve paces. Then suddenly turns on Furtwangler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi sticks her fingers in her ears and shuts her eyes tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve is stung. His eyes narrow dangerously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The telephone rings. No one moves. Then Emmi picks up the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Offers the phone to David.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David takes the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve indicates he'll take the call on the extension. Furtwangler stands. As Steve crosses to the extension:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks up the extension. Emmi puts down her receiver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes quickly. David dashes after him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Emmi, go get him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Furtwangler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't hear anyone invite you to sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to understand why you're here. You're automatically banned from public life under Control Council Directive No 24. We're here to look into your case before you appear in front of the Tribunal for Artists of the Denazification Commission. You understand that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have already been cleared by a Denazification Tribunal in Austria.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What they do in Austria doesn't interest me one little bit. Okay? I have your questionnaire here, (reading) Gustav Heinrich Ernst Martin Wilhelm Furtwangler, born Berlin, January 1886. Orchestral conductor. And you say here you were never a member of the Nazi Party.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is correct.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could you tell us about being made a Prussian Privy Councillor. How did that happen to a non-Party member?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I received a telegram from Hermann Goering informing me that he had made me a Privy Councillor. I was not given the opportunity either to accept or refuse. After the dreadful events of November 1938, the violent attacks on the Jews, I stopped using the title.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about Vice-President of the Chamber of Music, you used that title didn't you? But then I suppose you had no choice there either, because I suppose Dr. Goebbels just sent you a telegram saying, Dear Mr. Vice-President.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think Dr. Goebbels sent me a telegram. I was simply told. In a letter, I believe. I don't remember exactly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goebbels and Goering were sure heaping honours on you. One makes you a Privy Councillor, the other makes you Vice-President of the Chamber of Music, and you weren't even a member of the Party, how do you explain that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, there was a constant battle between Goering and Goebbels as to which of them would control German culture. I was simply a pawn. Anyway, I resigned from the Musikkammer at the same time I resigned as Musical Director of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra. In 1934.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why was that? Why did you resign, Dr. Furtwangler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wrote an open letter to the newspapers condemning what they were doing to music, making these distinctions between Jews and non- Jews. For my part, the only divide in art is between good and bad. Eventually, Goebbels summoned me and told me I could leave the country if I wanted to but under no condition would I ever be allowed to return. I always believe that you have to fight from the inside not from without. I asked myself, what's the duty of an artist, to stay or to leave? And then Goebbels demanded that I acknowledge Hitler as solely responsible for cultural policy. Well, that was a fact and it seemed pointless to deny it. I simply acknowledged that Hitler and the Minister of Culture appointed by him were solely responsible for the cultural policy of the Reich. What I wanted to express was that I, personally, had no responsibility whatsoever for their cultural policy. I have always had the view that art and politics should... should have nothing to do with each other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why did you conduct at one of their Nuremberg rallies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flaring) I did not conduct at at the rally, I conducted on the evening before the rally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That sounds like the small print in one of our insurance policies, Wilhelm. And what about April 19, 1942?  The eve of Hitler's fifty- third birthday, the big celebration; you conducted for Hitler, didn't you? Was that in keeping with your view that art and politics have nothing to do with each other?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flustered) That... that was a different matter, I... I was tricked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How come?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could I have a glass of water, please? Please, Fraulein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Straube.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. I was in Vienna, rehearsing the Ninth Symphony of Beethoven, when Goebbels called and said I had to conduct at Hitler's birthday. I'd always managed to wriggle out of such invitations, pleading previous engagements, illness, having my doctors state I was not well and so on and so on. I was also fortunate that Baldur von Shirach, who controlled Vienna, hated Dr. Goebbels and would do anything to thwart his wishes. But this time Goebbels got to my doctors before me; they were frightened off, and von Schirach was threatened, bullied and gave in. So, I had no alternative but to conduct for Hitler. Believe me, I knew I had compromised, and I deeply regret it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (playing with him) Doesn't sound much of a trick to me. Sounds like you made a deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I made no deal!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't buy that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I keep hearing you helped a lot of Jews to escape. How did you do that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't remember in detail, there were so many.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you call someone you knew?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I may have, as... as I said, I simply don't remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me me help you, then. You picked up the phone and made a call - (Mimes a telephone.) 'Hello, Adolf? Wilhelm speaking. Listen, old pal, there's a Jew-boy musician I want you to help. He needs a permit to get to Paris.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or maybe you called Goebbels or Goering? You were so close you were in the same shithouse as them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May I ask a question?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When will my case be heard by the Tribunal?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your guess is as good as mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need to work. I need to make my living. I live off the generosity of friends...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tough, tough!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (now more and more agitated) Then why is it, please, that another conductor who was actually a member of the Party, who used to play the Horst Wessel before his concerts, has already been cleared and is working again while I have to wait and wait and wait?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, he wasn't my case. Why did you escape to Switzerland just before the war ended?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was because I learned that the Gestapo was about to arrest me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why were they going to arrest you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I believe it was because of another letter I'd written to Goebbels lamenting the decline of musical standards due to racial policies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't complain about the racial policies, just about the musical standards, is that right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, how did you learn that the Gestapo was out to get you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: During an enforced hour-long interval because of a power failure at a concert here in Berlin, Albert Speer, the Minister of Armaments, said to me, 'You look very tired Dr. Furtwangler, you should go abroad for a while.' I knew exactly what he meant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sure knew a lot of people in high places.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It would be truer to say, I think, that a lot of people in high places knew me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were real close to all of them, to Adolf, to Hermann, to Joseph, to Baldur, and now Albert, (flaring) So, let's hear the truth, let's come clean. What was your Party number?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you are going to bully me like this, Major, you had better do your homework. You obviously have no idea how impertinent and stupid your questions are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: David, you remember I said I had a question that he wouldn't be able to answer? Well, I'm gonna ask it now.  You ready for this, Wilhelm? It's a tough one. Why didn't you get out right at the start when Hitler came to power in 1933? Why didn't you leave Germany?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a list of names here, people in your profession, who got out in '33. Bruno Walter, Otto Klemperer, Arnold Schoenberg, Max Reinhardt...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They were Jews, they had to leave. They were right to leave. (He breathes deeply, summons strength.) I could not leave my country in her deepest misery. After all, I am a German.  I... I stayed in my homeland. Is that my sin in your eyes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See, David? He can't answer the question. I'll ask it again, Wilhelm, and don't give me any more airy-fairy, intellectual bullshit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major Arnold's office. Yes, he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Major Richards for Lieutenant Wills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: David Wills. Yes, sir. (listens.) Well, you want me to tell him? Okay, (to Steve) Major Richards wants a word with you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (muttering) Why can't he just ask for me? Why does he have to ask for you first? Goddamn British, so correct!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Steve Arnold...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've had enough of this, I'm leaving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler is at the door when David reaches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sound of Steve laughing with delight.  Furtwangler hesitates. Emmi comes to the waiting-room door, watches, as if on guard. David comes round to face Furtwangler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He falls silent.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Furtwangler!  Dr. Furtwangler! Please, please... (a warning) Don't. It's not advisable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he gathers courage) When I was a child, my father, he took me to... he took me to one of your concerts. I remember you conducted Beethoven's Fifth Symphony. I was deeply moved. And I've loved music ever since. I was grateful to you. And I've admired you. How could you... how could you serve those criminals?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Emmi, at the open door, has been listening. She's shocked, turns away to see Steve, on the extension, chuckling, grinning from ear to ear. STEVE How many?  Jesus, that's dynamite! Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David and Furtwangler haven't moved. Both are looking towards Steve's office and Emmi in the doorway. Again the sound of Steve's laugh. Then Emmi steps into the room, approaches Furtwangler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives her a wonderful smile.  And, suddenly, Steve stands in the doorway, smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others are made awkward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler goes to the door. David opens it for him. Furtwangler nods, then turns to Emmi, bows to her and smiles. He goes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Furtwangler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well now. Aren't we all sociable?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got to hand it to the British, David. You know what those guys are?  Decent. (He sits, crosses his legs.) Tell me, Herr Dr. Furtwangler, do you know Hans Hinkel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, a despicable human being. He was in the Ministry of Culture. His job was to get rid of Jews in the arts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yup, that's him, that's the guy. You know what else the little creep did? He kept files, close on 250,000 files. And you know what's in those files?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly not, but I knew he had informers everywhere. Even in my orchestra there was someone
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wasn't told. I just knew it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uneasy) I was warned. STEVE Who warned you? FURTWANGLER (lowering his head) Goering. Because Hinkel was working for Goebbels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did Goering say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He told me to be careful as one of Goebbels' men was watching me. He read a report on me - everything I said was quoted word by word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh boy, you're gonna love this. Take your time with this now. Those files contain the details of every working artist in this country. Those files are gonna tell us who joined the Party, who informed and who was helpful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Your name, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a long trestle table running the length of the room, with chairs, as if in a library. A notice requests 'Silence'. British and American servicemen, a Russian and a French officer studying papers, making notes. At the furthest end, Steve, David and Emmi.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: David Wills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fantastic! The only condition is we have to do the work here. I want you to collect all the files on the boys in the band.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: David discovers that the archive room was originally a synagogue. He is moved. He lays stones on the rail of what was once the ark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi and David surrounded by files, sifting through, making notes. They examine the Hinkel Archive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another day. Sunshine pouring in. Steve seated as before, but Emmi and David again in different places. Emmi rises, goes to Steve, shows him something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reads. He is not pleased. He writes furiously. Emmi returns to her place. Suddenly, a movement causes Steve to look up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you can have a look at this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : David slides a note across to Emmi. Emmi reads the note. David watches her. She looks at him. She almost smiles, nods surreptitiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She feels Steve's eyes on her, and returns quickly to her work. Steve is displeased and even more suspicious.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (a whisper) Schubert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Summer evening. The first movement of Schubert's String Quintet in C Major, D956, played by three men and two women to a large audience packed into the ruins, partly open to the sky, Dymshitz  among them. At the rear of the church, Emmi and David, enraptured, seated side by side. The first movement ends and the Adagio begins. After the music gathers momentum: Rain. Thunder and lightning. The musicians continue to play, unperturbed.  They are coming to the end of the Quintet. David and Emmi huddled together. Some umbrellas up and then movement which catches David's attention. He nudges Emmi, I indicates with his chin. People have moved to reveal Furtwangler: seated, wearing a hat, still I' as a statue, soaked, listening, expressionless. Much applause. The musicians bow. The audience start to leave. Emmi and David emerge from the ruins.  Furtwangler passes them. They nod awkwardly. He doesn't respond but is about to walk on when Dymshitz pushes through, nods to David, who salutes. Dymshitz catches up with Furtwangler. They are near to Emmi and David.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods politely, is about to go -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler allows himself a faint smile, tips his hat, and then hurries off into the night. Dymshitz goes, too. David and Emmi watch them.  Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huddled under their umbrella, they dash off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Furtwangler -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Moving, you agree? Whenever I hear Schubert I am moved.  You agree?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The tempi were a little too correct for my taste. But I expect that is because of the rain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (also for David's benefit) Wait, Doctor, I understand you have difficulties with the Americans. I want you to know, I am your champion. We can help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frowning, worried) What does he mean, too correct?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve, fully dressed, lies on the bed in his small, shabby room, staring into space. He is suddenly startled by a loud roll of thunder and then a fierce crack of lightning. He goes to the window, watching the rain. He stands motionless for a second, then makes a decision. He grabs his cap, a raincoat from the back of the door. Another loud thunderclap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dancers jitterbugging and jiving. Among them, David and Emmi also dancing, imitating the others and having a good time. The music ends. Scattered applause. The band leaves the platform. The dancers return to tables or the bar. Later: David and Emmi at their table, eating. She eats voraciously, eyes glazed, all her concentration on the food in front of her. David is fascinated, can't stop watching her. Steve enters the club, makes his way to the bar, orders a drink. Steve turns to survey the room, almost at once spots David and Emmi, their backs to him. He observes them. David and Emmi at their table: They have finished their meal. Emmi is silent now, staring at her empty plate. Steve is suddenly at their table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: he band starts to play; he stands, holds out a hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is horribly embarrassed, doesn't move. David suddenly stands and takes Emmi by the arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They leave quickly. Steve watches them. He sinks down, angry and jealous.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what is this, the office party? David and Emmi are frozen with embarrassment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May I join you? (sits down, beams.) So, what have you two been up to tonight? Hey. Don't I owe you a bottle of French champagne? Tries to get a waiter's attention but fails.  No response.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, David, you're a lucky guy. I invited Emmi here but she turned me down. You must've hidden depths, David...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, Emmi, let's dance. I'll teach you how to jive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very sorry, Major, but I promised her mother, we have to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: David and Emmi enter the hall, each locked in their own thoughts.  They reach the foot of the stairs and pause. They want to kiss but both are too awkward. She starts up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops, turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She continues on her way.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't see me to my door, there's no need.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I promised your mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, sleep well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve and Emmi at work on the files. One or two BRITISH OFFICERS present, and David, who is working at the far end of the table. He has a cold. Emmi, who also has a cold, opens a file and is immediately alert. She reads. She blows her nose. She is uncertain. She looks up at Steve. She makes a decision. She rises, takes the file to Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She points to something. Steve laughs loudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David looks up at them, puzzled. Then a British SERGEANT comes into the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David rises and as he goes:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, Major. I found this on Helmuth Rode. You remember? The second violinist? Look, he's Austrian not German. But it's this that's more important, I think...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sssh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lieutenant Wills, telephone -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exasperated) What is this, a railway station?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In a booth near the front desk, David is on the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Irritated, he taps the receiver but the line's gone dead.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into telephone) David. Wills. Hello? Who? Who in Wiesbaden?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve lies, shirt off, taking the sun. Children playing. Noise behind him of someone in the bushes. Steve doesn't move. Rode, carrying a slender leather case, pushes through to Steve, who remains with his eyes closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode takes from the case a conductor's baton. Steve opens one eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sits up, takes the baton. Somewhere a child laughs; suddenly Steve thrusts the baton at Rode.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After nervous looks over his shoulder Rode, salutes half- heartedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode thrusts his hand out in the Nazi salute. People by the lake: Mostly elderly, but some younger ones see Rode saluting. Some turn away. Others stare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode and Steve: Rode looks around nervously, lowers his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A ball comes bounding towards them. Steve catches it. Then a BOY runs in, looks hopeful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve tosses the ball back to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve pats the spot next to him and Rode sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode makes an attempt to go but Steve grabs him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode suddenly starts to retch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People by the lakeside: Faces turning at Rode's sobs. Impassive. Blank. Steve and Rode:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode vomits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a moment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brief silence. Steve stands. Further along the lakeside: Steve and Rode walk. People about. Boats on the lake.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Major.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eyes still closed) Helmuth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Guess what I am holding in my hand. You like guessing games?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Love 'em, Helmuth. I give up. What are you holding in your hand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Dr. Furtwangler's baton, which I stole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The one he kept in his right hand. Yes, you remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, you remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How could I forget?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, show me, I want to see you do it. Pretend I'm Adolf. You're the maestro, and you have the baton in your right hand, but you give me the salute just the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not here, Major, there are people, if anybody should see... please, please, Major...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do it, Helmuth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do it right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You look great doing that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I see what you mean. You nearly poked my eyes out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly.  Replaces the baton, gives Steve the case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, Helmuth, it'll be our secret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mister, mister, here, here, mister!!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great catch, kid. The boy runs off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So. You wanted to see me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You usually don't work on Sunday, Major?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All in the cause of humanity, Helmuth. Or should I call you one- zero-four-nine-three-three-one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One-zero-four-nine-three-three- one. Or d'you mind if I just call you 'one'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what I say you are, Helmuth? I say you're a piece of shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That bastard!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's the bastard, Helmuth? Hinkel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? He promised to remove your file?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what about before that? What were you a member of in Austria?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was a member of...?  Speak up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (barely audible) I was a member of the Communist Party. I was a communist. That's what Hinkel had over me. He knew everything. He held that over me. That's how he made me co-operate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I see, he made you co-operate. And now are you a communist again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angry) You don't know what it's like to wake up every single morning of your life terrified, you don't know that - (he stops.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would never, in my wildest dreams, have ever been a second violinist in the Berlin Philharmonic. When they got rid of the... the Jews in the orchestra, it gave people like me a chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rode rowing Steve in a small boat. Rode, exhausted, stops. The boat drifts. Steve watches him for a moment, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode, trying to catch his breath, shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response. Rode keeps his head bowed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Then Rode slowly raises his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Helmuth, you ever heard of plea- bargaining?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Talk about power, I have the power to give you work, make your life easier. Your past won't be mentioned. I could give you a job tomorrow but I have to get something in return. See, Helmuth? That's plea-bargaining.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can give you freedom of movement, freedom to work, freedom, Helmuth. But I need something in return.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major, we're discussing a man of genius, I don't want...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck that, Helmuth. You want to discuss symbols here?  This guy was a front man. He was the piper, but he played their tune, you get my philosophical meaning?  I'm not interested in small fish, I'm after Moby Dick. Come on, Helmuth. Hard facts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The only thing I know is he's an anti-Semite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course. You, too. Like everyone else in this goddamn country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rode and Steve walking. Rode suddenly turns to him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start to walk away from the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops, takes out a cigarette, offers one to Rode, lights them both, gives Rode the packet.  They smoke for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sun is setting. Rode stops suddenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode tries to make up his mind about something, then decides. He reaches into an inside pocket and takes out a small black notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rode hesitates, then he hands Steve the black book.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've remembered something else...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Furtwangler sent Hitler a telegram for his birthday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He did?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One of your people told me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One of my people?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. A corporal. US Army. A Jew. He said he'd seen the telegram in the Chancellery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Son-of-a-gun. We'll find the corporal and we'll find the telegram.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I need documentary proof. You know of anything like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. But that's why we hated him. We admired him as a conductor but we all hated him too because he didn't have to join the Party and yet he had a better life than any of us. He didn't have to go and deliver a report after every trip abroad. He got everything from them, everything. He was filthier than any of us Party members.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a rumour... I don't know if it's true or not... but ask him about von der Null.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never heard of him, who is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Edwin von der Null. Music critic. He gave Furtwangler terrible reviews while he raved about Herbert von Karajan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Also a conductor. Very brilliant. Young. Von der Null called him 'The Miracle von Karajan'. Furtwangler was outraged and they say he had von der Null conscripted into the army. The same thing happened to another critic. True or not, it's not such a bad idea. Critics give you bad reviews, you have them sent to the Russian front. (Chuckks.) But if you really want to get Furtwangler, ask him about Herbert von Karajan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Miracle Kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, yes you may notice that he cannot even bring himself to utter his name, he... he refers to him as K.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And ask him about his private life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His private life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, it's all in here. His women.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve going along the shelves filled with files. He's at the H, then I, then J. He stops at the letter K. With his forefinger, he runs down the files. He stops, pulls out a fat file: 'KARAJAN,H.VON' He opens the file. INSERT: - the file:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of an energetic-looking young man and two Nazi Party membership booklets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David makes his way from the counter. He carries a tray with two cups of coffee. He goes to a table where CAPTAIN MARTIN sits, papers and files spread before him. David gives him his coffee, then sits across from him, blows his nose. Silence while they sugar and milk their coffee. David aware of Martin's eyes on him. MARTIN Where do you stand on all this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He breaks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Passes papers across to David.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David tries to sneeze but fails; he starts to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He watches David read. David is engrossed. Almost imperceptibly, he shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: On all what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On Furtwangler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You represent the United States now. We have a moral duty to be just and we have to be seen to be just.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major Arnold believes he has a moral duty, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our duty is to help Furtwangler with his defence, (carefully) That's why I want you to look at this... (he selects papers from the table.) These are part of the transcripts of the trial at Nuremberg. We can't get them translated fast enough. But I guess you understand German, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the evidence of a guy named Dahlerus. He's a Swede. Friend of Hermann Goering. I want you to study it. And I want you to use it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going to find more stuff to feed you. We'll have some other suggestions. We need to build a case for the defence - based not on feelings, not on prejudice, but on facts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A half-ruined cafe with tables on the sidewalk. WERNER, the timpanist, SCHLEE, the oboist, and two others seated at one of the tables, drinking coffee. David carries an attache case and walks towards the cafe. He scans the people at the tables, sees the musicians and approaches. They stand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David nods
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David leaves money on the table and then walks off with the four men. They talk as they make their way down a side street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lieutenant Wills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Schlee, timpanist, Herr Romer, cello and Herr Schmidt, viola. They are willing to help. We have already ordered ourselves coffee. I hope you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The whole orchestra will vouch for him. He was always there to support us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We need names, if possible with addresses, because it's urgent. Names of musicians saved by Dr. Furtwangler, people he helped to escape abroad. Let's go somewhere public.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve and Dymshitz sit opposite each other and clink vodka glasses.  They have been drinking but are not yet drunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They drink. Dymshitz pours more vodka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is still for a moment, then grabs the bottle and pours himself a drink, downs it. Dymshitz watches him, then:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: To co-operation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was in Vienna. I had with me an Austrian chauffeur, Max his name was, he spent time in the camps. We were looking at these Viennese cleaning up the bomb damage, scavenging for rotting food, butt ends, anything. I said, 'To think a million of these people came out to welcome Adolf on the day he entered the city, a million of 'em, and now look at 'em.'  And Max said, 'Oh, not these people, Major. These people were all at home hiding Jews in their attics.' You get the point, Colonel? The point is they're all full of shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Furtwangler's in a different category.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're dealing with degenerates here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Degenerates?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: German modern paintings stacked untidily. Dymshitz, carrying a vodka bottle and his glass, shows Steve the paintings. Steve, too, has a glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dymshitz pours vodkas, raises his glass, drinks. So does Steve. Now, their moods swing with the drink. Dymshitz drinks; then sits, sinks into his own world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A forlorn look at Steve. His eyes are misty, he is visibly drunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dymshitz bursts out laughing. Stung, Steve advances on him, almost as if he's about to attack him physically. He stops, sways a little, then, after a moment, drops down in a chair near to Dymshitz. They drink. Intimate:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A great artist will have great privileges in a Russian zone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why he didn't get the hell out of here when he had the chance! I put that to him, he couldn't answer. Why didn't he go and direct in America, like that Italian, Toscanini.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lost for a moment) Perhaps... perhaps he believed he could at least try to preserve something important, things like an orchestra, a school. That's his country. Maybe he has an old mother who can't be left alone. Maybe he has brothers, sisters... you can't...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a wry smile) Colonel. He had no sisters, no brothers, only a lot of love affairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway, Major, why should he leave his country, his mother tongue, his family, his history, his past, his future, just because now, suddenly, there is a dictatorship? Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what... before that turns rotten...  What if they surround the space with barbed wire, Colonel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly exploding) Don't talk about things you know nothing about. He was in a dictatorship!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dismissive) Yeah, yeah, art and politics, yeah, yeah, I heard all about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angry) In a dictatorship, art belongs to the Party. If you want to be a conductor, you have to have an orchestra. And you can only get an orchestra if you have contact with the power. All over the world you need the right contacts and you have to make the right compromises.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is what I'm saying. He must have had Party contacts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are good Party members who help, and there are dirty non-Party members who inform on you. Of course, they gave him privileges.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And suddenly, Steve, suddenly you notice that they like you. They honour you, suddenly you are the director of the best museum in the world, for example.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What museum?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. Museum? Not... I said orchestra. Sorry. Believe me. (another sudden change of mood to earnest, intimate) Help me, Steve. You say you answer for someone from high up. I, too, have orders from high up. Very high up. We want Furtwangler. I'll give you in return the whole orchestra, four, five conductors. I need him, Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No can do.
dialogue.name: dialogue
