dialogue.raw_text: Let Furtwangler go. Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a duty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flaring) Duty? I am sorry, duty? Duty fucking duty. Trouble is, you Americans want everybody to live like you. We liberated Berlin, Major Steve, not you. Our duty also is to bring back the best of German culture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm gonna get that fucking bandleader, Colonel. No deal. No fucking deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you're going to kill me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Drunk, Steve is clumsily, almost frantically, threading film into the 16-mm projector. He switches off the lights then stumbles back to the projector, turns it on and directs its beam towards a blank square of watt. It's an American military propaganda film.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve, swaying slightly, watches, with the film continuing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'll see ruins, you'll see flowers, you'll see some mighty pretty scenery, don't let it fool you. You are in enemy country. The Nazi party may be gone, but Nazi thinking, Nazi training and Nazi trickery remain. Somewhere in this Germany are two million ex-Nazi officials. Out of power but still in there and thinking, thinking about next time. Remember that only yesterday every business, every profession was part of Hitler's system. Practically every German was part of the Nazi network. They believed they were born to be masters. Don't argue with them. You are not being sent Germany as educators. You're a soldier on guard. You will observe their local laws, respect their costumes and religion and you will respect their property rights. You will not be friendly. You will be aloof, watchful and suspicious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bright summer's day. Emmi pushing her way through the crowded market. She comes to the stall with gramophone records. David is with her, staying behind a little so as not to disturb her. She starts to look through the records, blowing her nose from time to time. Then she finds a box of records, opens it, is delighted. She bargains with the stallholder, and she hands over money. She shows her purchase to David happily. They struggle on in the crowd. David suddenly stops. He has spotted a tandem. The bicycle with two seats is old and rusty but seems to be in working order. David steps up to it, touches it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two persons, Emmi and David, riding the tandem. Emmi in the front, pedalling, David behind. The road going up into the hills is full of potholes. They change seats. David is in the front, Emmi at the back. Suddenly the road begins to descend. They change again, Emmi sits in the front, David at the back. They speed down the hill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tandem, ridden by Emmi and David, rolls into a huge building, black and burnt out. In the middle of the vast hall, surrounded by the staircase, there is a Christmas tree, almost burnt to cinder. Emmi and David stare at it, mesmerised.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yesterday I read that Furtwangler was asked to lead the New York Philharmonic back in '36, Toscanini suggested it. Had he accepted, he would have become the most celebrated conductor in America.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When he made his decision, he couldn't have known everything. Especially not the way people like you do, who've returned from exile and feel that you have a right to pass judgement. Because you are blameless, you think you know best who is a sinner and who deserves forgiveness. But you have no idea how people lived here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When he met Hitler at his birthday and shook hands with him, was he pleased?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. But you and I already know that he has saved lives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve and David studying files in silence.  Furtwangler's baton is on Steve's desk. Steve drinks black coffee. Emmi enters.  Curt nods of greeting. She goes to her desk, then takes the Bruckner record to Steve. Steve looks at the record, then glances up at Emmi. He does his best to exclude David, who tries to hear what is said. Emmi glances at David. She's embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He returns to his desk. Emmi looks through the album for the appropriate record.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bruckner's Seventh, Major.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know where the Adagio begins?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put it on ready to play, and I'll tell you when to play it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve by the open window, looking at his wristwatch, smoking a cigarette. David and Emmi both watch him.  The door opens and Furtwangler bursts in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler goes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David and Emmi gaze at him as he tries to regain control.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is now nine o'clock precisely. I do not intend to be kept waiting again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dangerously calm) Don't talk to me like I was a second violinist. Go back into the waiting room. Miss Straube will come and get you when I am ready to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus God, who the hell does he think he is? Who the hell does he think he is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The door to the landing is open and Rode is there pretending to sweep. He looks in to see Furtwangler sitting, holding his handkerchief over his nose and mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler doesn't seem to hear. Rode hesitates, then continues to sweep.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Would you perhaps like to have a glass of water, Herr Professor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: David and Emmi look at him, puzzled. She goes to the door, opens it, nods. Rode quickly disappears.  Furtwangler looks at Emmi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi doesn't answer. All eyes on the door.  Furtwangler enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler, deeply suspicious, goes for the uncomfortable chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds the other chair for Furtwangler, who sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler takes from his pocket a piece of paper with notes. He blows his nose. The room is warming up. It will become like an airless court room, a pressure cooker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David and Emmi exchange the briefest of looks. David raises his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler rises angrily and starts to pace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits heavily, wipes his brow. He is sweating now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brief silence; all eyes on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response. To Furtwangler:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve goes to his desk and, as Furtwangler rises uncertainly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Steve turns on the projector and the Bergen-Belsen film flickers into life.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is this man doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Furtwangler!  Come in, come in, sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, take this one, it's more comfortable
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If it's too hot, open your tie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) I wish to say something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead, be my guest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I last saw you, I was unprepared. I did not know what to expect. In these past weeks, I have been thinking more carefully and making some notes. (glances at the notes.) You have to understand who I am and what I am. I am a musician and I believe in music. I am an artist and I believe in art. Art in general, and music, in particular, has for me mystical powers which nurture man's spiritual needs. I must confess, however, to being extremely naive.  I insisted for many years on the absolute separation of art and politics. My entire life was devoted to music because, and this is very important, because I thought that I could, through music, do something practical.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maintain liberty, humanity and justice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gee, that's a thing of beauty, honest to God, a real thing of beauty. I'm going to try to remember that. Liberty, humanity and justice. Beautiful. But you used the word 'naive'. Are you now saying you think you were wrong? That art and politics can't be separated?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I believe art and politics should be separate, but that they weren't kept separate I learned to my cost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And when did you first learn that - when you sent the telegram? Was that the surrender signal, the waving of the white flag?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What telegram?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Happy birthday, dear Adolf, love Wilhelm.' Or words to that effect. That sounds to me like you were dropping on your knees and saying, 'Okay, Adolf, you win. You're the number one man. Have a swell party.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have no idea what you're talking about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The birthday greetings you sent to your old pal, Adolf Hider.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never sent him any birthday greetings or any other kind of greetings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Think carefully, Wilhelm... maybe not in your own name, but as Privy Councillor or Vice-President.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't have to think carefully. This is utterly ridiculous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, David?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not show Dr. Furtwangler the evidence. It may refresh his memory?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't find it because no such telegram exists.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I tried, you got to admit I tried. I thought I might just trap you there, Wilhelm, but David here was too quick for me. Smart move, David, smart move. No, I don't have the telegram, but I know it exists. And I want you to know, Wilhelm, we're going to keep looking for it because I believe you sent it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you are wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Art and politics, yeah, art and politics. Let's look at that. You and the Berlin Philharmonic toured the Third Reich, played in countries the Nazis had conquered. Are you saying that conducting in occupied territories from 1939 on wasn't a commercial for Adolf and all he stood for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We never, never officially represented the regime when we played abroad. We always performed as a private ensemble. As I think I already told you, I was a freelance conductor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know something? You should've written our insurance policies for us because you got more exclusion clauses than Double Indemnity. What do you imagine people thought? The Berlin Philharmonic's taken over by Doctor Goebbels and his Propaganda Ministry but Wilhelm is a freelance, so art and politics are now entirely separate? Is that what you believed ordinary people thought?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: have no idea what ordinary people thought.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, because I had only one intention. My only intention whatever I did was to show that music means more than politics.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me about von der Null.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taken off-guard) Von der Null?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, von der Null.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Von der Null?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long's this going to go on, Wilhelm? I say von der Null, you say von der Null, I say von der Null, you say von der Null, we could go on all day. You know who von der Null is, don't you? Edwin von der Nuell, music critic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I know who he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't it true that because he gave you bad reviews and praised this young guy, Von Karajan, called him a goddamn miracle, said he was a better conductor than you, then you had von der Null conscripted into the army and no one's heard from him since?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's an outrageous lie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sure you didn't call one of your close buddies and say, God in heaven, did you see what that guy von der Null wrote about me? The greatest conductor on earth. I want him out the way. He had the nerve to accuse me I am not playing enough modern music. Send him to Stalingrad. Isn't that what you did? You don't like criticism, do you, Wilhelm?  You surely didn't like them saying there was another conductor who was better than you... Are you saying the name von der Null was never mentioned in your talks with Goebbels?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncomfortable) Well. Once he said he'd read what this man wrote about me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what did he say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He said, 'Don't mind him. His job is to criticise, your job is to conduct.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what happened to Von der Nul?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have no idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've really no idea? I'll tell you what happened. He died in Stalingrad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. STEVE Now, that young conductor what's his name? (playing with Furtwangler) That miracle kid, you know who I mean. Von Karajan! But you called him something else. C'mon. What did you call von Karajan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll say it, then. 'Little K.' Is that right? You couldn't even bear to say his name!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please stop playing these games with me. Why you should bring up the name of another conductor is beyond my understanding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell you why. You remember we talked about you playing for Hitler's birthday?  And you told me that Goebbels got to your doctors first, that you were tricked?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, that's what happened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a different story to tell. I don't think you were tricked. Not in the way you describe. I believe something else happened. I've seen the Hinkel Archive, I've seen records of phone calls, and putting it all together, this is what I think happened. I think Goebbels said, 'Wilhelm, if you won't conduct for Adolf's birthday, we'll get the Miracle Kid, the guy that critic, von der Null, thinks is the greatest conductor in the world. He's not just willing to conduct for Adolf, he's offered to sing "Happy Birthday" as a solo.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, admit it. K worried you, didn't he? He always worried you. In 1942, he's thirty-four years old, you're already fifty-six. And Goebbels and Goering keep saying to you, 'If you don't do it, little K will.' Never mind art and politics and symbols and airy-fairy bullshit about liberty, humanity and justice because I don't care how great you are. It's the oldest story in the book, (a wry look at David) The ageing Romeo jealous of the young buck. The real reason you didn't leave the country when you knew you should have was that you were frightened that, once you were out of the way, you'd be supplanted by the Miracle Kid, the Party's boy twice over, flashy, talented little K.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is absolute nonsense!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm just beginning to develop my theme. Isn't that what you call it in classical music, developing your theme? Okay, so they played on your insecurity. That's human, understandable. But, there is one guy who doesn't like little K as much as he likes you - yeah, the number one man your old pal, Adolf. He thinks you're the greatest, and when he says, I want Wilhelm for my birthday, boy, they better go out get Wilhelm. So, Josef calls and threatens you with little K. And you said to hell with the Ninth in Vienna, I'll give it to Adolf as a birthday present in Berlin. That's the trick they played, they got you by the balls and they squeezed. Hard. Why did you stay? Why did you play for them? Why were you the flag-carrier for their regime?  Jealousy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) Of course there was a conspiracy against me, a campaign - even abroad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see, Wilhelm, I'm talking about ordinary, everyday reasons. Which is why I want to discuss your private life.  How many illegitimate children do you have?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major, I don't see how this line of questioning could...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: David, what are you Counsel for the Defence now? ( (to Furtwangler) Did you hear the question?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (barely audible) I have illegitimate children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said I have illegitimate children. I don't know how many.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You like the women, don't you, Wilhelm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't it true that before every concert you got a woman in your dressing room and gave her the old conductor's baton, isn't that true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating EmmI) Major, this is deeply offensive and repugnant!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You bet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: and totally irrelevant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing to Furtwangler) Not so, Counsellor. That secretary of yours, she wasn't just your secretary, she procured women for you, didn't she? As many and as often as you wanted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop this, please, stop this now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm not going to stop it. Hitler himself offered you a beautiful house and a personal bomb shelter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I absolutely refused the house and the bomb shelter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you see what I'm getting at? You get a gorgeous house, you're highly paid. What are you gonna do, stay or leave? One voice comes back at me: stay!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major, that's not a good argument. If Dr. Furtwangler did indeed enjoy all these... these privileges, he enjoyed them because of who he is and what he is. That's true of any leading artist in any country in the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it still doesn't make them saints. They still have to get up and piss in the middle of the night, don't they? They can still be vindictive and envious and mean just like you and me. Well, just like me. Can't they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Wilhelm, go home now. Go home and think about these past twelve years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understand what you mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, that's your problem, Wilhelm. You understand nothing. We'll call you. Go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your manner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My manner? Why don't you go downstairs, get a cup of coffee and calm down? What's the matter, Emmi? What's going on with you? What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry but I have to leave. I'll find other work. You'll have to get someone else, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this, Emmi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't do this. It's not right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's not right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have been questioned by the Gestapo just like that. Just like you questioned him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Emmi, stop! I want to show you something. Let me show you something and then if you want to leave, you can leave, please please. His friends, they did this. And he gave them birthday concerts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he had no idea, a lot of people had no idea. I only realised what was really going on when I got arrested.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he had no idea, why did the Jews need saving? This is the question, Emmi, to all Germans: Why did the Jews need saving in this country? Why, if people had no idea?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would like to go now, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Band playing. Couples dancing. David and Steve at the bar, each with a drink in front of them, lost in their own thoughts. Then: Steve signs to the barkeeper to fill their glasses but David puts a hand over his glass. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to go, then comes back to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The customers stare at him as he stalks out. The band plays.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can I ask you a favour, Major?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you question him again, could you treat him with more respect?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With more what? More what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major, he may just be the greatest conductor of this century and that merits respect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flaring, hissing) David, I don't understand a thing about you. You're a Jew. Are you a Jew?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I'm a Jew. But I like to think first I'm a human being.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A human being, oh, good, I'm relieved, I thought you were going to say you were a music lover. This man, this great artist has made anti-Semitic remarks like you wouldn't believe. I got letters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major, show me someone who hasn't made an anti-Semitic remark and I'll show you the gates of paradise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over-reacting and overlapping) What is it with you, David? Where are your feelings? Where's your hatred, your disgust? Where's your fucking outrage, David?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Think of your parents, David, and then think of him conducting 'Happy Birthday, dear Adolf'. I mean, for Chrissake, whose side are you on? Grow up! Just grow the fuck up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: David and Emmi, sitting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to come back to the office. May I come in? If you are there you can influence what happens. What good can you do by leaving. If you go, you are giving up and how can you help Furtwangler or me? Don't think about leaving. Stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hot, Windows closed.  Furtwangler seated. David and Emmi present.  Steve looks up from his notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve tenses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holds up his package of letters and dumps them on Emmi's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi is uncertain. Steve shrugs indifferently. She picks an envelope and takes out the letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi puts on the record of the Adagio from Bruckner's Seventh Symphony. After a moment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music plays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David takes the record off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An uncontrollable surge of anger wells up in Steve, causing him to pace alarmingly. He grabs the baton from his desk, stands trembling before Furtwangler, and snaps it in half. He pushes his face close to Furtwangler, who recoils, terrified. David half-stands, ready to intervene physically. During this Emmi puts her fingers in her ears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sees Emmi has her fingers in her ears, yells at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She does so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She screams. Stillness. All eyes on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He breaks down, buries his face in his hands, weeps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is suddenly overtaken by nausea and faintness, stands, a hand to his mouth. Emmi goes to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emmi helps Furtwangler out. Steve strides to the window, opens it, puts his head out into the fresh air.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody says what a great benefactor you were to the Jews. But-- (holds up a sheaf of papers.) I have things here you said and wrote. Listen to this: 'The Jew composer Schonberg is admired by the Jewish International.' And what about this: 'Jewish musicians lack a genuine affinity with our music.' 'Jewish musicians are good businessmen with few scruples, lacking roots.' You deny you said these things?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those attitudes do not exist in me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I believe that. But just answer the question, don't give me explanations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Speaking to Party members I used their language, of course I did, everyone did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with some irony) Major, sorry to interrupt, but maybe we have to... maybe we have to balance those things against his assistance to his Jewish colleagues.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is a transcript of the proceedings at Nuremberg. A Swedish businessman, Birger Dahlerus, testified in cross- examination that he had several meetings with Hermann Goering. 'I first saw Goering,' Dahlerus testified, 'embroiled in a stormy interview with Wilhelm Furtwangler, the famous conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, who was vainly seeking permission to keep his Jewish concert master.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Emmi, pick one of these, any one, read it out loud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) 'Please remember that Dr. Furtwangler risked his life to help anyone who asked him. I personally testify to having seen literally hundreds of people lined up outside his dressing room after concerts to ask for his help. He never turned anyone away. After he heard me play... I am a violinist... he gave me money because I was unable to feed myself or my family and then he helped me to escape to Sweden. He helped countless people in similar ways.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And this, only one of these letters, Major. I have lots of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) How many times have I got to tell you I was in insurance? You think I can't smell a phoney policy when it's shoved under my nose? Sure, he helped Jews, but that was just insurance, his cover, because all the while he was maestro of all he surveyed, (turning on Furtwangler) See, Wilhelm, I think you're their boy, their creature. You were like an advertising slogan for them: this is what we produce, the greatest conductor in the world. And you went along with it. The truth of the matter is, Wilhelm, you didn't need to be a member of the Party. I made a mistake when I asked you for your Party number. I should've asked you for your non- Party number. Just like some other well-known artists. (suddenly, to Emmi) Emmi, put that record on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know what that is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I know what that is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, so what is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bruckner's Seventh. The Adagio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's conducting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know the last time it was played on these air waves?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can I know such a thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell you, then. The last time this music was played on these air waves was after they announced that your pal Hitler had shot himself. Listen to it.  They listen. Did they pick little K's recording? Did they pick some other conductor? No, they picked you, and why? Because you represented them so beautifully. When the Devil died, they wanted his bandleader to conduct the funeral march. You were everything to them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (near to breakdown but struggling for control) I have always tried to analyse myself carefully and closely. In staying here, I believed I walked a tightrope between exile and the gallows. You seem to be blaming me for not having allowed myself to be hanged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't directly oppose the Party because I told myself, that was not my job. If I had taken any active part in politics I could not have remained here. But as a musician, I am more than a citizen. I am a citizen of this country in that eternal sense to which the genius of great music testifies. I know that a single performance of a great masterpiece was a stronger and more vital negation of the spirit of Buchenwald and Auschwitz than words.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quiet, terrifying) Have you ever smelled burning flesh? I smelt it four miles away. Four miles away, I smelt it. Have you ever seen the gas chambers, the crematoria? Have you seen the mounds of rotting corpses? You talk to me about culture, art and music? You putting that in the scales, Wilhelm? You setting culture, art and music against the millions put to death by your pals? They had orchestras in the camps. They played Beethoven, Wagner. The hangmen were playing chamber music at home with their families. I don't understand the Germans' relationship with music. What do you need music for? Your pals you could call to save a few Jews when millions of them were being annihilated? Yes, I blame you for not getting hanged, I blame you for your cowardice. You strutted and swaggered, you fucking piece of shit, king-pin in a shithouse. You talk to me about walking a tightrope between exile and the gallows, and I say to you, lies!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (breaking down) I love my country, I believe in music, what was I to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look around you. See the country you served. Look at people who had real courage, who took risks, who risked their lives. Like Emmi's father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Emmi, take your fingers out of your ears!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm talking about your father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father only joined the plot when he realised that we could not win the war.  She cries quietly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (desperate) What kind of a world do you want, Major? What kind of world are you going to make? Do you honestly believe that the only reality is the material world, so you will be left nothing, nothing but feculence... more foul-smelling than that which pervades your nights... (near to breakdown) How was I to understand, how was I to know what they were capable of? No one knew. No one knew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to stay in this country. Yes, I should have left in 1934, it would have been better if I'd left...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get him out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Emmi helps Furtwangler to a chair. She watches him solicitously. He breathes deeply.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Fraulein. You have been most kind. (he rises.) He smiles at her. She is embarrassed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve is trying to get a number on the telephone. David is packing up his papers. David turns to the records, starts to son through until he finds what he's looking for. He removes the Bruckner and puts another record on the turntable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At full volume the sound of the subdued opening of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But David ignores him, sits, implacable, listening.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into the telephone) Major Arnold. Get me General Wallace. General? Major Arnold, about Furtwangler. I don't know if we've got a case that'll stand up, but sure as hell we can give him a hard time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to David) Hey, turn that down, would you? Can't you see I'm on the phone? (into the telephone) Never mind, we got a journalist who'll do whatever we tell him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler walks slowly down the stairs, a broken man struggling to regain his composure. Emmi watches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music at full blast. David, at an open window, keeps his back to Steve, still on the telephone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Turn it off!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler, on the stairs, stops, hearing the music echoing through the building. Furtwangler left hand begins to tremble, but it is only his way of sensing the tempo. Furtwangler slowly continues down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We handed Wilhelm Furtwangler over to the civil authorities and he was charged with serving the Nazi regime, with uttering anti-Semitic slurs, performing at an official Nazi Party function and with being a Prussian Privy Councillor.  Dr. Furtwangler was acquitted. I didn't nail him. But I sure winged him. And I know I did the right thing. Furtwangler resumed his career but he was never allowed to conduct in the United States. He died in 1954. Little K succeeded him as head of the Berlin Philharmonic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Furtwangler conducting. Goebbels and other high-ranking Nazis in the audience. When the music finishes, Furtwangler turns and bows. Goebbels rises and shakes hands with him. Furtwangler takes his handkerchief and wipes his hands. The film replays this gesture several times - Furtwangler wiping his hands.
direction.name: direction
